Award.AwardTitle: UTeachEngineering: Training Secondary Teachers to Deliver Design-Based Engineering Instruction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Texas at Austin's Cockrell School of Engineering is partnering with the successful UTeach Natural Sciences program and the Austin Independent School District to develop and deliver UTeachEngineering, an innovative, design- and challenge-based curriculum for preparing secondary teachers of engineering. To meet the growing need for engineering teachers in Texas, and to serve as a model in engineering education across the nation, UTeachEngineering has the following four professional development pathways to teacher preparedness, two for in-service teachers and two for pre-service teachers:

1. UTeach Master of Arts in Science and Engineering Education (MASEE);
2. Engineering Summer Institutes for Teachers (ESIT);
3. Engineering Certification Track for Physics Majors; and
4. Teacher Preparation Track for Engineering Majors.

Key elements of the four UTeachEngineering pathways are four new engineering courses focusing on engineering content and pedagogy: Fundamentals in Engineering and Design, Knowing and Learning in Engineering, Engineering Energy Systems, and Design of Machines and Systems. Leveraging these four courses in combination with existing UTeach pedagogical courses, UTeachEngineering anticipates reaching 650 teachers (80 pre-service and 570 in-service) over the first five years. In the future, it is expected that UTeachEngineering will be sustained as a vital program at the University of Texas at Austin.

UTeachEngineering is firmly rooted in current research in the field of engineering education and affords a much-needed opportunity to study the teaching and learning of engineering. During the development phase, UTeachEngineering is examining impacts on three specific groups: (1) Engineers involved in the creation of curricular materials and course design, (2) participants (current and future teachers) enrolled in the engineering courses, and (3) the students of these teachers. While the focused goal of UTeachEngineering is to train a cadre of secondary teachers, the project's vision is that all students are "engineering enabled," acquiring the design and interaction skills that would enable them to be successful in an engineering career should they choose one, while enhancing their lives and participation as global citizens even if they do not become engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
UTeachEngineering (NSF 08318110), a National Science Foundation Math and Science Partnership, based at the University of Texas at Austin, developed a year-long, design-based high school engineering course and supporting teacher education and training programs.  The course, Engineer Your World (www.engineeryourworld.org ), is an innovative, student-centered experience that engages learners in authentic engineering experiences and inspires them to embrace an engineer’s habits of mind. The course combines rigorous core engineering concepts with cross-discipline perspectives to deliver a rich sequence of socially relevant, student-directed challenges. The project-based curriculum engages students of diverse backgrounds, abilities, and interests, in a wide range of educational environments. The project has been particularly successful in reaching students who are traditionally underrepresented in engineering; in 2015-16, 29 percent of students were female and 45 percent were Black or Latino/a.

Initially launched in seven schools in central Texas, Engineer Your World was refined several times based on teacher feedback and research by learning scientists.  In 2016, at the end of the National Science Foundation funding period, the course was being offered in 165 schools in 20 states. More than 11,000 high school students have taken the course, with almost 7000 more enrolled for the 2016-2017 academic year. Thanks to an innovative licensing fee structure developed and implemented by the University of Texas project team, the program has achieved sustainability for the foreseeable future. Furthermore, thanks to investment by funders including the University of Texas System and the AT&T Foundation, the network of schools offering Engineer Your World is expected to continue to grow at a rapid pace. 

The project team at the University of Texas has provided summer professional development to prepare teachers to offer Engineer Your World. Beginning in the final project year, to expand capacity, the professional development model  evolved into a “train-the-trainer” approach that leverages the considerable experience and expertise of the  Engineer Your World teacher community. Each new Engineer Your World teacher now receives initial training and ongoing support through a peer-led cohort model that includes two years of intensive induction support. Over the period of NSF funding, 373 teachers participated in professional development activities related to the Engineer Your World program.

The project also did considerable work with teachers seeking to become leaders in secondary engineering education. In collaboration with the Colleges of Education and Natural Sciences at The University of Texas, the team developed undergraduate pathways for students seeking STEM degrees and teaching certifications as well as a Master of Arts degree in STEM Education.  Over the NSF funding period, 15 students completed the undergraduate program with an engineering focus and 53 teachers earned the MA degree.
